metadata.h1: How I Made A ChromeBook My Data Science Daily Driver

all_paragraphs: ChromeOS has come a long way in recent years, and has become a much more viable alternative to buying a traditional, bulky, expensive laptops running Windows 10. Recently, Chromebooks have been granted the ability to install and use Android apps from the Google Play Store. For apps with sufficient optimization, this can be fantastic; getting a full-screen, perfectly normal experience of an android app, as if you were working on an Apple IPad with a dedicated keyboard. The apps run quite well, as you might imagine. Chromebook processors, for the most part, are huge contenders against a standard Android phone processor, and have the same base architecture, ARM64.

But with a laptop, there are a lot of things that need to be done that apps can’t do. Fortunately, Google’s problem of straying too far from Linux has been remedied to some extent by now allowing the installation of Linux applications from a Debian-based repository. So now in ChromeOS, we have the compatibility with ARM64 applications inside of Debian repositories, as well as android applications.

So when looking for my Chromebook, those two were my big requirements. The laptop needed to have the aptitude package manager (the package manager I use every day,) and likely would also need to be able to run Android Applications. These two major features are only in addition to the features that ChromeOS comes with in the first place. The ChromeOS UI isn’t my favorite but is definitely clean, pretty, and usable.

In my closet sits around 20 Lenovos of various eras, Thinkpads, Yogas, so obviously when I came across a Lenovo C330 Chromebook on the web listed for $30, I jumped at the opportunity. Not only would I be able to tinker with a Chromebook, but I’d also add to my Lenovo collection!

The Lenovo C330 is a great budget Chromebook, although it is ABS plastic, it feels rather solid. The keyboard is okay, a little squishy, and the trackpad is perfect for the system. It’s a convertible, like my Yoga 910, but likely due to the bezels, size, and Android app compatibility, I actually do end up using the laptop in tablet mode, something that can’t be said for my Yoga 910. Also, I hate to say it, but USB-C/Thunderbolt-3 charging is an absolutely enormous plus for me, as I love using

Firstly, it should be noted that I’m a computer collector and computer fanatic. Adding to my collection is always a great thing. In addition to this, I’m a huge Unix fan, and distro fan. So in short, I wanted a new toy to play around with, but there are also some key benefits to using a Chromebook that are staples in the Chromebook name.

Battery life is a key focus of many Chromebooks, and is frequently targeted by Google specifically in their Chromebook advertisements is battery life. The Chromebook I decided on charges fast, and gets around ten hours of battery life on average. Of course this varies a bit, but compared to my current daily driver, it usually doubles run time.

Additionally, I use a lot of Google Play Services, as I’m an Android user as well. Google Play Music, Google Play Movies, the convenience is certainly there, as on my daily driver I can’t download anything from Google Play.

Out of the box, Google is already bragging about their low-level APIs and compatibility layers, asking for Android apps you’ve installed on your Google account to install onto your Chromebook. From these apps I chose Slack and Zoom, two apps I frequent on a daily basis. Both apps are perfectly usable on the Chromebook, so, fortunately, it’s not looking like we’ll need to replace either of them. In addition to these suggested apps, the first setup will place a little folder called “ Linux Applications” into your app drawer, with a terminal application inside. Of course, this is the first thing I did on my Chromebook, prior to even opening Google Chrome.

And now we have Julia, but there is a big problem… The latest version of Julia is 1.2, and the latest version in apt available for ARM64 is 0.4. And with that, there’s a pretty serious Pkg bug, no Pkg REPL, and a lot of packages including Lathe for machine-learning will not be compatible with this version of Julia.

Fortunately, we are on a virtual Debian machine, which means the galaxy of the hardworking contributors to GNU free software will cater directly to us. Debian Stretch comes pre-loaded with MultiArch, and it is rather easy to configure. So once again, we will edit our sources file, but this time we will change all mentions of “ stretch” to “ buster”. Write it out, close nano, and update your sources.

For Julia, I was able to get amd64 Julia running with MultiArch using the Debian 10 Buster repositories. So now I can officially dub my Chromebook as my

ChromeOS really has come a long way from its netbook-like history. This is a great thing, because it makes Chromebooks a viable alternative, whereas previously it was not. Now you have the potential to use applications like Kdenlive, Gimp, and Open-Broadcaster Software for multimedia use, nearly every programming language, libre-office, and even system managers like Gparted. I had seen a lot of talk about installing .deb files from the internet to install, and the short-hand given with arm64, but never anybody who tried to use MultiArch! So I hope that Chromebook owners will appreciate being able to get a bit more out of their Chromebook!
